item.title: My personal file server on a Cubox from SolidRun using Arch Linux

description.p: For my file server I have the following requirements:

ol.li: it should consume as less as possible electricity
it should be very silent, means no active cooling
the operation system should use OpenSSH

description.p: Thus, for the hardware I have decided to use a Cubox from SolidRun because it has a very good value for money. Notice that I use the first revision of the Cubox and not the Cubox-i serie. For the operation system I use Arch Linux because it is more up-to-date then the Debian or Ubuntu distribution.
Download the latest version of Arch Linux for the Marvell ARMv7 platform from the official site. Next, plug your MicroSD into your computer and find out which drive (/dev/sdx) it is

pre.code: df -ah

description.p: Clear your disk and create one ext3 partition.

pre.code: mkfs.ext3 /dev/sdx1

description.p: Know mount it and extract Arch Linux onto your MicroSD partition

pre.code: mkdir /media/arch mount /dev/sdx1 /media/arch tar -xzvf ArchLinuxARM-cubox-latest.tar.gz -C /media/arch umount /media/arch rm -rf /media/arch

description.p: The default login is user root with password root.
Now lets configure some basic stuff, like date and time, DHCP, etc.

Create the /etc/systemd/network/eth0.network file so that it resembles the example below. Be sure to change the IP addresses to reflect the values shown under the “Remote Access” tab of the Linode Manager.

pre.code:
[Match] Name=eth0
[Network] DHCP=both

[Match] Name=eth0
[Network] Address=10.0.1.2/24 Gateway=10.0.1.1

description.p: Restart systemd-networkd. To do so, run this command:

pre.code: systemctl restart systemd-networkd

description.p: If you are on a network with DHCPv4 that filters Client IDs based on MAC addresses, you may need to change the following line in /etc/dhcpcd.conf:

pre.code: # Use the same DUID + IAID as set in DHCPv6 for DHCPv4 Client ID as per RFC4361. duid

description.p: to:

pre.code: # Use the hardware address of the interface for the Client ID (DHCPv4). clientid

description.p: Else, you may not obtain a lease since the DHCP server may not read your DHCPv6-style Client ID correctly. See RFC 4361 for more information.
To automatically start the DCHP daemon at start up you have to enable it.

pre.code: systemctl enable dhcpcd
pacman -Syu

description.p: If you have bad experience or strange behaviour with the standard vi simply install vim.

pre.code: pacman -S vim-minimal

description.p: Change your timezone to the one your are living at. All time zones can be found in the folder /etc/timezones.

pre.code: # To check the current zone defined for the system: timedatectl status # To list available zones: timedatectl list-timezones # To change your time zone: timedatectl set-timezone Europe/Zurich

description.p: Also do not forget to change your locale

pre.code: localectl status ls /usr/share/i18n/locales localectl set-locale LANG=de_CH.UTF-8

description.p: For internal file sharing you could use Samba. Tips and tricks can be found on Arch Linux Samba site

pre.code: pacman -S samba

description.p: Your can restart the service using the follwing

pre.code: systemctl enable smbd.service systemctl enable nmbd.service

description.p: Create a new samba group

pre.code: groupadd sambashare

description.p: and add user to it

pre.code: # add user to the samba grup pdbedit -a -u samba_user # changing samba password smbpasswd samba_user

description.p: Adding a user to the samba group

pre.code: usermod -a -G sambashare unix_user_name

description.p: On my Cubox I use the following configuration (/etc/samba/smb.conf):

pre.code:
[global] workgroup = iocast server string = file server # Share-level security: Each share in the workgroup has one or more passwords associated with it. Anyone who knows a valid password for the share can access it. # User-level security: Each share in the workgroup is configured to allow access from certain users. With each initial tree connection, the Samba server verifies users and their passwords to allow them access to the share. # Server-level security: This is the same as user-level security, except that the Samba server uses another server to validate users and their passwords before granting access to the share. # Domain-level security: Samba becomes a member of a Windows NT domain and uses one of the domain's domain controllers—either the PDC or a BDC—to perform authentication. Once authenticated, the user is given a special token that allows her access to any share with appropriate access rights. With this token, the domain controller will not have to revalidate the user's password each time she attempts to access another share within the domain. The domain controller can be a Windows NT/2000 PDC or BDC, or Samba acting as a Windows NT PDC. security = user map to guest = bad user create mask = 0775 force create mode = 0775 directory mask = 02775 force directory mode = 02775 force group = sambashare
[share 1] comment = data disk path = /storage/data/ public = no writable = yes guest ok = no valid users = user1 user2 write list = user1 read list = user2
[share 1 backup] comment = data disk backup path = /storage/backup/ public = no writable = no guest ok = no valid users = user1 write list = user1
[share 2] comment = data disk1 path = /storage/data1/ public = no writable = yes guest ok = no valid users = user1 user2 write list = user1 user2
[share 2 backup] comment = data disk1 backup path = /storage/backup1/ public = no writable = no guest ok = no valid users = user1 user2 write list = user1 user2
[scans] comment = documents from scanner path = /storage/scans/ guest ok = yes guest account = user1 available = yes browsable = yes public = yes writable = yes

description.p: To automatically mount disks on startup, you need to add them to the /etc/fstab configuration file. Also use the option nofail to not report any error if the disk is absent. For more information read the manual on Arch Linux
Run lsblk -f or ls -l /dev/disk/by-uuid to list the partitions / disks. Edit the /etc/fstab and prefix the values in the UUID column with UUID=:

pre.code: # <file system> <dir> <type> <options> <dump> <pass> UUID=54940062-befb-4127-b1fc-15584cd4c2ea /storage/data/ ext4 nofail,rw,relatime,data=ordered 0 0 UUID=e786913c-ee77-4e04-a0d6-1b70b2b4ff69 /storage/backup/ ext4 nofail,rw,relatime,data=ordered 0 0 UUID=92e833e1-ecc4-4cd3-9874-969867eb5848 /storage/data1/ ext4 nofail,rw,relatime,data=ordered 0 0 UUID=b5a1514e-6a87-4ea5-a3ce-a592a41abecc /storage/backup1/ ext4 nofail,rw,relatime,data=ordered 0 0

description.p: If you use afraid.org as your dynamic DNS service you can get an example cron entry from the Dynamic DNS menu entry. It look likes the following

pre.code:
PATH=/sbin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin
3,8,13,18,23,28,33,38,43,48,53,58 * * * * sleep 37 ; wget -O - http://freedns.afraid.org/dynamic/update.php?key= >> /tmp/freedns_pasithee_mooo_com.log 2>&1 &

description.p: On Arch Linux you need to do the following changes to use it with systemd/Timers (see here). First we need to create a new timer vim /etc/systemd/system/afraid.org.timer and add the following lines

pre.code:
[Unit] Description=timer for service afraid.org.timer Requires=network-online.target Requires=network.target After=dhcpcd.service
[Timer] OnCalendar=*:3,8,13,18,23,28,33,38,43,48,53,58
[Install] WantedBy=multi-user.target

description.p: Then create a service file of the same name /etc/systemd/system/afraid.org.service and add the following lines

pre.code:
[Unit] Description=service for afraid.org for pasithee.mooo.com
[Service] Type=simple ExecStart=/usr/bin/curl -k http://freedns.afraid.org/dynamic/update.php?key= >> /tmp/freedns_pasithee_mooo_com.log 2>&1

description.p: Now you can test the service.

pre.code: # test service systemctl start afraid.org.service systemctl stop afraid.org.service

description.p: As soon as it works you can enable the timer

pre.code: systemctl enable afraid.org.timer systemctl start afraid.org.timer
